dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beginning title sequence: the CAMERA TRAVELS gracefully o a woman's body. The BLACK AND WHITE images are smooth, classy, beautiful. This sequence continues until we've se every part of a woman's body that we can see in a PG-13 m Finally, the woman's hair fills the screen. It is long, flowing, thick black hair. The final title fades in:

dialogues.speaker: EVIL ANGEL
dialogues.text: And then, in SLOW MOTION, the woman's hair parts. The CAM SPEED rapidly increases as color fills the screen, and a terrifying, ghostly white face thrusts itself toward us. The eyes are red in black sockets. The demon's teeth are razor sharp, and there is blood in her mouth. She screams

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEOFF MORGAN screams, too. He staggers back on a busy str and bumps into a YOUNG COUPLE on a date. Geoff, 34, is dressed in a long, black coat. Beneath the coat he wears nice shirt and a loose necktie.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Hey, watch it, man. But Geoff keeps staring ahead, at two HOOKERS who stand against a brick building. They look back at him, startled One of them has long black hair, but her face is quite hu Terrified, Geoff turns and runs. He pushes his way throug the crowd. He sees the marquee of a movie theater: CHARLIE CHAPLIN'S CITY LIGHTS with LIVE ORCHESTRA. TONIGHT ONLY. Geoff runs to the ticket booth of the theater. The girl a the ticket booth is looking down at her cash drawer. She hears Geoff and she looks up, but she's not the pimply-fa teenager we expect. She's the demon. She screams through blood-filled mouth. Geoff shouts and staggers backward into the street. A tax swerves to miss him. Geoff looks back at the ticket booth but the demon is gone. A sweet-looking, and very confused TEENAGED GIRL watches from behind the glass. Geoff spins around. He sees a huge, blue neon cross attac to the top of the building across the street. He lurches toward the building and steps directly into the path of a oncoming ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance driver, JENNY, swerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Shit! Jenny, 26, is a street-hardened beauty. Riding shotgun is MARCUS GALAN, 27. He's not tall, but he's dark and handso He has the radio mike in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Whoa!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I almost killed that crazy bastard! You see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff staggers across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus is on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Unit 5 in transit. We're two minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff pounds on the doors of the church building. The doo are locked. Two YOUNG WOMEN approach on the sidewalk. Frightened, Geoff runs to the adjoining building, a hotel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff stumbles into the hotel. The small lobby leads into classy restaurant. A sexy HOSTESS waits at the podium, he back to Geoff. She is speaking with CAMILLE JENSEN, 30, a nicely-dressed hotel manager. As Geoff approaches, the hostess turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: May I help you, sir? As she speaks, her voice and her face turn demonic. Geoff shouts. He runs to the elevator. A WELL-DRESSED COU is inside. The door is closing. The woman sees Geoff approaching. She reaches out to stop the doors. Geoff sees the woman's hand. It has turned into a claw. H shouts. He goes for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Jenny burst into the lobby of a low-rent downt apartment building. There is no elevator. They go directl to the stairs and start up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff runs up the stairs. We see deep down into the stairwell. He is several flights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Jenny get to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: 413. This is it.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Where's the welcome party?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (bangs on the door) Hello! A woman shouts from the other side of the door.

dialogues.speaker: KARINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ayudame! Marcus tries the door. It is locked.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (to the woman inside) The door is locked! Can you open the door?

dialogues.speaker: KARINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No! Por Favor! Ayudame!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Knock it down, man. Get macho. Marcus steps back. He kicks the door hard, near the handl The door bursts open, splintering the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff bursts out onto the roof. He is exhausted. He sees the top of the huge neon cross. He closes the doo behind him. He runs to the cross. He embraces it. He look around, insane with fear. The door to the roof blows open

dialogues.speaker: GEOFF
dialogues.text: No! But there is no one there. He puts a leg over the short wall. He climbs out onto the ledge, and he holds to the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Jenny drop to the floor where a young latina, KARINA, 15, lies on some pillows and sofa cushions. She i very pregnant and is in labor. The telephone is on the fl next to her. She wears a gold crucifix around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: It's alright. We're here. We're here.

dialogues.speaker: KARINA
dialogues.text: Me estoy muriendo! Mi hijo, esta muriendo!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: No, no. Esta bien. Ya estamos aqui. Vas a estar bien. Marcus quickly pulls on his plastic gloves and reaches un the girl's skirt.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: She's at ten. Looks like we're having a baby. (to Karina) No te empujes. Esta bien. Tu bebe estara bien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd exits the movie theater. They are dressed in suit and evening gowns. A 5-year-old BOY holds his parents hands as they start ac the street. He looks up. And stops.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Batman.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: What did you say, honey?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (points up) Batman. The parents look up. They see Geoff on the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: No, honey. That's not Batman. (to her husband) David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get somebody. Dad runs back toward the building. Others see the Mom and little boy looking up. They also look up. Word begins to spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff clings to the cross. His shoe slips on the ledge. H holds tighter. The metal brace on the sign creaks. A bolt dislodges from the brick. This sign is not going to hold.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Here he comes. The girl groans. Shawn kneels beside her head. He brushes the hair from her face.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You're almost done, girl. Karina looks down and watches the baby crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff looks down. Quite a crowd has gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some SECURITY GUARDS try to move the people back away fro the building. The Mom, Dad, and boy move back. A squad ca arrives and two COPS jump out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bolt pulls out farther. Geoff gasps. He reaches out and grabs the ledge. Camille, the hotel manager, steps out through the open do onto the roof. She's wearing a dress, but no coat. She holds her arms close to her body as she approaches. Geoff sees her. He steps back onto the cross. The metal braces groan. He looks down and then back at her. She sto several feet away.

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: Sir? He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I--I work for the hotel. I don't know what...I'm supposed to do. Another bolt dislodges. Camille gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karina shouts again.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He's got the cord around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (to Karina) You're gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Twice. Dammit. Jenny looks at Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's alright. I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff looks down at the circus below. Then back at Camill She looks toward the open door, as if expecting help. She holds out her hand

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: You've got to give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFF
dialogues.text: I--I can't.

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: The sign's going to fall. You've got to give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFF
dialogues.text: I'm scared. The bolt pulls free.

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: Give me your hand!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Got it! (to Karina) Empuje!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign begins to slide.

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: Now! Two policemen arrive at the door. Geoff puts out his hand As his hand touches Camille's fingers, he sees that her h has become a claw. He looks up into her demonic face. Her mouth and eyes open wide.

dialogues.speaker: NOOOOO
dialogues.text: He yanks his hand back. His feet slip. He loses his balan He spins around. Camille gasps. For a brief moment, Geoff hangs in the air, his arms stretched out at his sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy looks up at Geoff.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Batman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then Geoff falls, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille stares at the empty space that Geoff had just occupied. Geoff falls, at first slowly, gracefully. He picks up spe

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He's coming. He's almost here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the concrete sidewalk coming up fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille watches Geoff fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy watches, in horror. Geoff's body lands face-up on the roof of a car. The car' windows explode. The crowd recoils. THE CAMERA RACES at lightning speed from the hit, through the crowd, to a CLOSE-UP on the Boy's wide-eyed face. A speck of blood hits his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille turns away.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Got him! Marcus lifts the baby. The child is male. He's covered in blood, but isn't crying. Jenny has a suction bulb ready.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (into her radio) We got an APGAR of...two. Marcus sucks the mucous from the baby's nose and mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd freaks out. Mom kneels at the Boy's level.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Charlie, honey? Are you okay? He turns to her. She sees the blood on his cheek. She gas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille swoons. The policemen arrive. They hold her up. One of the cops looks down at Geoff's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff isn't quite dead. He looks up at the neon cross, wh still clings to the rooftop above. His eyes glaze over. We see Geoff's fading point of view of the cross. The ima DISSOLVES TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The silver crucifix around Karina's neck. Her breathin is labored. She looks at the baby. Marcus turns the baby over in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, little man! The baby shivers, and then breathes, then cries.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There we go!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (into the radio) We got him. He's breathing.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (cradles the baby) He's gonna be just fine. (to Karina) Bien bonito. Mira. Esta bien. Karina smiles, still breathing heavily. She sinks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Jenny push a gurney through the main doors of emergency room. Karina and her baby are on the gurney. A DOCTOR meets them.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: How's the little guy?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He's 100 percent. Already nursing.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: How long was he without oxygen?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe a minute or so. Another EMT approaches. This is SHAWN, 28, a black man wh expresses as much reggae as his uniform allows.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Okay. Good job. We'll check him out.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Marcus, you on the clock?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I just brought this girl in--

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: We got a stabbing on Fifth South. Jen can handle the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I gotta--  10.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Come on! We got blood!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Right. (to Jenny) Busy night.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance races through the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn drives. Marcus is riding shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: So you're a daddy again. How many does that make?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Five, counting this one.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: You think she's gonna name it after you? Shawn laughs. Marcus smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance stops at a homeless shelter. Three police cars have already arrived. A crowd of HOMELESS MEN AND WO has gathered. Two COPS stand at the door to the shelter. Marcus and Shawn grab their kits and enter the building. One of the policemen leads them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The policeman leads Marcus and Shawn into a huge room lin with tables. There are plates of uneaten food on the tabl Two POLICEMEN stand near a HOMELESS MAN who kneels near o of the benches. His hands are cuffed behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: She's over here. The policeman leads Marcus and Shawn into the kitchen are A small crowd has gathered around a young woman who is ly on the floor in a pool of blood. FATHER CARLISLE, 58, an Episcopal priest, is holding the woman's hand. He rises a Marcus drops to one knee at the woman's side.  11. He has blood on his hands. She is young, in her early 20's, and innocently pretty. This is EMMA. A long, bloody kitchen knife lies on the fl only a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: She was stabbed, I don't know...four or five times. I tried to stop the bleeding. Shawn is immediately on his radio. Marcus sees the girl's face. He is instantly confused.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (unsure) I know this girl.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: We've got a female, early 20's, multiple stab wounds to the abdomen. We need O negative standing by.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: Emma. Carillo.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Emma, can you hear me? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to help you through this, alright? But you're gonna have to help us, too, okay? She nods. Her eyes close. Marcus touches her face.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it hurts, but you're gonna have to stay awake for me. Can you do that? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We gotta move her. Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn drives. They are racing through the city with a pol escort. Marcus is in the back with Emma.  12.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: We're almost there, Emma. You stay with me, you hear? Emma touches his hand. She says something.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? What was that?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: ...Name.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You want to know my name? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's Marcus. She manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Marcus...

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What is it? What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: ».-love...you... Marcus is speechless. He looks down at her. She lightly squeezes his hand. There is something so beautifully peac in her expression, in her eyes. Then her grip loosens. Her eyelids close. She's losing consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Emma, stay with me! Emma! She loses consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shawn! I'm losing her!

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: We're almost there!  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance pulls in. Marcus kicks the doors open as tw ER NURSES and a doctor, ROLLINS, meet the ambulance. They all pull the gurney out.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: She lost consciousness three minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: We've got her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rollins and the nurses push the gurney through the hallwa Marcus walks with it.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Her name is Emma Carillo. She was talking just three minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: We've got her! Marcus stops outside the trauma room door. He watches thr the window as the medical team attempts to resuscitate he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn fills out paperwork at the reception desk. Jenny approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Where's Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Trauma 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus watches through the window. Emma has been hooked u to a monitor. She has flat-lined. Rollins uses the defibrillator. No response.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What you got?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Female. 23 years old. Some sick bastard turned into Jack the Ripper.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Nice.  14.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: I think Marcus might've known her. Jenny exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus watches. The Doc gives it another try. Nothing. Jenny joins Marcus at the window.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: How's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: She's coming back. The doc tries one last time.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Emma. The Doctor calls it.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: God. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: No. Marcus throws the door open and enters.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's not dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? Marcus approaches the defibrillator.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Get back.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Get away from that body!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I said get back! He shocks her. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Marcus! Stop it!  15.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: She's dead!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Back off!

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: You crazy son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Clear! He shocks her again. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Marcus, leave her alone. She's dead, man.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: (to a nurse) Get security. The nurse hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (to Emma) Come on...CLEAR! He shocks her again. Nothing. He takes her face. He breathes into her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, Emma. Come on! He presses on her chest. He breathes into her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman, CAROLINE, 26, awakens suddenly in a hospital bed She is alone in her room. She is hooked up to tubes and wires. She looks around, disoriented, but without anxiety She sits up. She starts to free herself from the wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarms begin to beep and blink on the nurses' console No one is at the station. They are all attending to the situation with Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: This is crazy. You're gonna get arrested! Marcus presses on Emma's chest. He breathes into her mout  16.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Marcus!

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: She's coming back! Two SECURITY GUARDS rush in. Marcus presses on her chest again. The guards and the doctor grab Marcus. He fights.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emma! Emma! Goddammit! As they pull him away, the nurses move toward the body.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! They turn off the monitors.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No!! Rollins covers her with the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline walks into the hallway. She sees the commotion. She watches for a moment, gently bites her lower lip, the walks in the opposite direction. No one notices her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus is seated in a plastic chair in the hallway. He is cuffed. Three security guards stand nearby. Shawn and Jen stand several feet away with Rollins and LATHROP, 48, a hospital administrator.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP
dialogues.text: I ought to have him arrested.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: He's a good medic.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP
dialogues.text: He's already in hot water over that hooker he killed last week.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Come on, man.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: That wasn't his fault and you know it!  17.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Look, man. He knew this girl.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What harm did he do? She was already dead.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: C'mon. We'll owe you one. Lathrop shakes his head and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE CUFFS being unlocked. Lathrop stands next to Marcus. Jenny and Shawn hang back.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP
dialogues.text: You had damn well better behave when you're in my hospital. Do you understand? Marcus nods.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Dr. Rollins gives a disgusted sigh and starts off.

dialogues.speaker: ROLLINS
dialogues.text: I'm putting in a call to Jack Henderson. This isn't over. Rollins collides with a MALE NURSE. The nurse recovers an turns to Lathrop. Marcus stares into the O.R. at Emma's lifeless body.

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Lathrop, we're missing a patient.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: She was unconscious five minutes ago. Now she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP
dialogues.text: (back to Marcus) Your behavior here was unacceptable. Absolutely unacceptable.  18. Marcus isn't even looking at Lathrop. He's still looking Emma's body.

dialogues.speaker: LATHROP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Shawn and Jenny) You keep him under control. Whatever he does, I'm holding both of you responsible. Shawn nods. Lathrop turns and follows the male nurse.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (to Marcus) You did know her, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON FIRE EXSTINGUISHER. A woman's hands remove it fr its hook on the wall. A young nurse, JO, 22, is kissing DANNY, 27, a maintenanc man. Danny gives her a small box tied with a ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I got you something.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Open it. She opens it. It is a necklace with a gold heart.

dialogues.speaker: JO
dialogues.text: Oh my god. She looks at him, adoringly. Caroline rises up behind Dan and smashes the back of his head with the fire extinguish The force of the blow throws his head into Jo's face, bre her nose and bouncing her head against the brick wall. Danny falls. Blood pours from Jo's nose. She's too dazed to scream. Her vision blurs, doubles. Caroline waits unti Jo's vision clears, then slams the extinguisher into the girl's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline exits the hospital. She wears the nurse's unifor and she wears it well. Damn, she's hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn drives the ambulance into the station driveway. Mar is in the passenger seat. They stop and wait as the bay door opens.  19.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Maybe you just saw her at the grocery store or something.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: No, it's like, I don't know...it's like I really knew her. Like she was close to me.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Reincarnation. You knew her in a previous life.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Total bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: You never know, man. The universe, it's one crazy place, you know?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I just...I knew her.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Well, it's a mystery. Marcus moves to get out.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you going? It's thursday. We're gonna get some beers.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I'm goin' home. Gotta clear my head.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Jen's coming.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I'm going home to my wife.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Alright, man. Just don't go back to the hospital. Lathrop will have your balls in a jar.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He'd probably sell ‘em on the black market.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Man, the black market don't have no interest in your teeny little Mexican balls.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Go to hell.  20. Marcus closes the ambulance door. Shawn drives the ambula into the open bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus pulls his green Mustang into the driveway of an ag rambler. He turns off the lights. Other cars are parked o the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus enters. The lights are off. He doesn't turn them on. He starts down the hallway. On the walls are family photos, several of Marcus and Carla, his wife. As he approaches the door, he hears muffled sounds. He st listens. He silently turns the doorknob. He pushes the door open a few inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus's wife, CARLA, 25, has a nice body, which is being enjoyed at the moment by ED, 31. Marcus stands in the doo and watches. After a moment, he quietly turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus starts down the hall. He stops. He looks at a photograph on the wall. It is his wedding photo. He smash the photo with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Carla jump out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Oh! Marcus!

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus punches the other photos on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed grabs his pants and climbs out the window.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Oh! Shit! Go, go!  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed falls from the window onto the garbage cans. He scramb to his feet, gathers his clothes, and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus attacks the wall until all of the photos are down. He looks at his bleeding knuckles. At the other end of the hall, Carla steps into the doorwa She holds a sheet against her chest. Marcus looks at her. She starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the malfunctioning neon sign of a fleabag motel, a Marcus's Mustang in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus sits at a tiny table near the window. He pours som Wild Turkey into a cheap plastic hotel cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla stands at the sink. She looks at herself in the mir She looks down at her arm. We see that her forearm is scarred, the remains of old cuts. She takes a razor blade and makes a tiny slice in the ski of her forearm. It hurts, and bleeds. She does it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus holds up the cup of whiskey. He looks at it. He makes a decision. He pours the whiskey back into the bott

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KENNEDY, 38, a morgue worker, pulls back the sheet on Emm Marcus looks down on her.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: They're gonna take her over to County. Marcus nods.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the deal?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I should've saved her.  22.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Paramedic guilt, huh? Dude, she was stabbed six times. In the gut. Even if you'd saved her, she would've been a mess for the rest of her life.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You mind if I sit here a while?

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't care. I'll be across the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: (turns back) Hey, you're not turning into your old partner, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Martineau. He used to come down here, sit with the bodies. Stare into their eyes. Talk to 'em sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I'm not turning into Martineau.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY
dialogues.text: That's good. 'Cause he's crazier than a shit-house rat. Marcus looks down at Emma's face.

dialogues.speaker: KENNEDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There wasn't anything you could do, man. She was dead before you even showed up. Kennedy goes. Marcus touches Emma's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus sits at a wooden table. An ATTORNEY sits beside hi Shawn, Jenny, and other off-duty EMTs are seated behind h Two of the medics are uniformed. One of them is JACKSON, 30, a muscular and bald-by-choice white guy. Several gruesome photographs of a dead young woman are pi to a bulletin board nearby. There is also a magnified dri license photo of the woman, LIZZIE MARKHAM, 20.  23. Seated apart from the medics is a large man in a rumpled suit. This is JOHN CARRUTHERS, 54. JACK HENDERSON, 48, a heavy-set man who appears to be in charge, is seated behind a large desk, which is on an ele platform. Four other EXECUTIVES are also seated on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: It is noted that Ms. Markham was wearing the medical identification tag, which identified her as a diabetic, around her ankle instead of around her neck or wrist as advised. CLOSE ON PHOTO OF WOMAN'S WRIST, NECK, and ANKLE. Then TR MARKS ON HER ARM, and, finally, A FULL BODY SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was clearly difficult for Mr. Galan to locate the tag, which although on her person, was effectively hidden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK to the night of Lizzie's death. We see Marcus a Jenny enter a crackhouse apartment. Lizzie is unconscious on the floor near an unmade fold-out sofa bed. From her wardrobe, she is clearly a hooker. And not an expensive one. From the junkie paraphernalia on the floor nearby, it's clear that Lizzie has recently shot up. Marc kneels at her side. He checks her jugular vein for a puls

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Due to the presence of heroin at the scene, Mr. Galan's decision to administer Narcan was appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: However, the presence of several empty liquor bottles clearly led Mr. Galan to presume that Ms. Markham's subsequent lethargy was due to intoxication rather than diabetic shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus prepares the syringe. Jen, in the background, talk on her radio. We see others in the room. We will later come to know them as RAY, PETRA, and JOSIE.  24. Marcus injects Lizzie with the drug. Lizzie moans and rol her head. A moment later, she is racked with a seizure.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: It is noted that once the patient seized, Mr. Galan correctly identified her condition, but his efforts to resuscitate her were unsuccessful. Marcus looks down at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are still too many uncertainties in this case. Although we believe that Mr. Galan will ultimately be found faultless in this incident, we feel that it is in his best interest, and in the best interests of this company, to delay our decision until a full investigation can be made. Henderson looks to Carruthers. Carruthers nods.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the meantime, we find it prudent to place Mr. Galan on suspension without pay. Jenny reacts with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should the investigation clear Mr. Galan of any wrong-doing, he will be compensated for lost wages during this period of suspension. Mr. Galan, do you understand the action that is being taken?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: Do you have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HENDERSON
dialogues.text: These proceedings are adjourned until the 14th of October. Everyone rises and begins to disperse. CLOSE ON PHOTO OF LIZZIE'S DEAD FACE.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn and Jenny walk Marcus to his car.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: That's bullshit, man. It's in their best interest to find you guilty. Then they don't have to pay you.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Don't be an idiot. If they find him guilty, then they've got a lawsuit. This is all just to show that they're taking some kind of action.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: That's bullshit. You gotta fight the man.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Fight the man? What is this, 1969? Fuck the man. That's what I say.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: That's right. They laugh, tap fists. Marcus looks toward a small park. He sees Carla waiting for him. Shawn and Jenny also see her.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Give me a call. We'll catch a flick tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I'll make you dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Alright. Thanks. I'll see you guys. They go. Marcus walks toward Carla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus is seated with Carla on a park bench. It has been difficult conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I don't even want to know. It wasn't me. That's all that matters.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: It's over. I swear. He's...he's a real jerk. I just--Marcus. I'm such an idiot.  26.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (rising) I've heard all this before.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I...I still love you.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: We don't have kids. We don't really have much stuff. It shouldn't turn into a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I don't want a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: And I don't want a wife who has sex with other men. She turns away. He notices the fresh cuts on her forearm. She doesn't hide them.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta go. I'll get an attorney, I guess. I've never done this before.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Me neither. He turns and goes. She tries not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NEWSPAPER article on last night's jumper. VICTOR CARRUTHERS, 34, is reading at his desk. He sets the newsp down. He appears anxious, afraid. There is a knock on the door. Vic's father, the detective we met earlier at Marcus's tribunal, sticks his head in. There's a strong family resemblance.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Hey, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I gotta take off. You want me to lock up?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: (concerned) You alright?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah...yeah. Have a good weekend.  27.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: You, too. Carruthers goes. Victor looks back at the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers walks through the empty reception area. He exi We watch through the pebbled glass as he locks the dead b from the outside. Stenciled on the pebbled glass:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Carlisle helps unload boxes of canned food from a small delivery truck. Marcus approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Father? Carlisle looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was hoping I could talk to you for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: You're one of the paramedics. Marcus nods. Carlisle steps away from his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlisle's office is stacked with books, files, mounds of fundraising fliers, stacks of donated clothing.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: She just came in here one day and picked up a broom. She was seventeen then. I told her she was too young. But she just kept sweeping. She said she was tired of playing silly games with the girls at church. She wanted to be a real Christian. Make a real difference. And then she just kept showing up. The Little Flower.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: That's what I called her. 'Cause she reminded me of Saint Terese.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I haven't been to mass in years.  28.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: Terese died young, too. Emma, she was as good and pure as any saint that ever lived. She truly was... Our God is a cruel God, I think. To allow such violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor closes his door and locks it. He turns and is star by a young woman who is sitting in the waiting room. It i Caroline. She wears a sexy black dress.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Did I startle you?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. I didn't--

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Do you have a few minutes? My business won't take long. He looks her over. She's hot, as we've mentioned before, and she's showing a lot of thigh. She gently bites her lo lip.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Sure. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Thank you. He unlocks his door. She rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers gets out of his car. He has parked in front of an old brick apartment building. He starts up the steps. black hooker, JOSIE, 19, sits on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Hey, papa. You a cop?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: You lookin' for skull? It's fifty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Sorry, little sister. Not today.  29.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: You better get it 'fore it's gone, baby. Carruthers enters the building. The hooker turns her attention back to the street.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (talking to herself) I'm the best there is, old man. Worth more'n fifty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline, seated, crosses her legs. Victor leans against edge of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What can I help you with, Ms.--

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Lilith...will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Lilith. What can I do for you? Caroline takes a cigarette case from her purse. She opens it. She starts to take what looks like a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't allow smoking in my office. She raises the cigarette a few inches from her chin.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Who's smoking? She puts the object in her mouth and we see that it isn't cigarette. It is a small tube. She blows. A tiny dart sticks in Victor's neck, near the jugular. He grabs his neck. He chokes. He slowly sinks to the floor. He looks up at Caroline. She puts the tube back into its case, and she removes a real cigarette. She lights it. Fr Victor's point of view, we watch as she uncrosses her leg and inhales a lung full of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of a dead bolt, unlocking. Then the doo opens. RAY, 48, a slumlord who moonlights as a pimp, lead Carruthers into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: This is it. Not much to look at.  30.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Thanks. The place is as depressing as any apartment on earth. Din dirty, smelly. Peeling wallpaper and cheap furniture.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: The cops already combed over everything. But Carruthers looks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If somebody don't come claim it this week, I'll just throw all this shit out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus opens the door to his house.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Carla?...You here? He stands, alone, in the center of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus packs his things into boxes. He packs his cd collection, his DVDs, his books. He looks up at two World War I swords that are crossed and mounted over the mantle Beneath the swords is a framed photograph of a WW I soldi Marcus sighs, then goes back to his task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers opens a chest of drawers.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I don't know where she came from. Just wandered in one day like a stray dog. Acted like she owned the place. Carruthers closes the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline opens a file cabinet. She's looking for somethin No luck. She opens another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus packs his clothes into a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers opens the drawers in the kitchen area.  31.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You sure you're not a cop?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I'm not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You used to be, though. Didn't you? Carruthers looks at him, but doesn't answer. He continues searching the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor begins to regain consciousness. He finds himself flat on his back, spread-eagle on his desk, his wrists an ankles tied securely to the legs of the desk. Caroline is crouched near the file cabinet. She reads a file. She notices him. She takes the file and puts it in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What is that? What do you have?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: You don't believe in the supernatural, do you, Mr. Carruthers? I tried to communicate with you, but you just wouldn't see me. You've put me through a lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What do you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: It's easy to slip into an occupied body for a few seconds. Just to make a point. But it's a lot harder to find a vacancy. It's a very competitive marketplace out there. Caroline sees a family photograph on the bookshelf. Victo has a wife and two kids.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, look. Are those babies proud of you? I bet they are. Of course, they don't know what Daddy's been up to, do they? Victor tries to free himself. It's pointless.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet you make a lot of sacrifices for your family, don't you?  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers looks on the bookshelves. There are no books. Just trinkets, stones, chrystals. And a diverse collectio of knives: daggers, antique shivs, ceremonial blades.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: She was into all kinds of shit. Supernatural stuff, you know. Witchcraft. Devil worship. Carruthers picks up the most interesting knife. It has a silver handle and a black, curved, snake-like blade.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: There's one more sacrifice you need to make.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What are you doing? What do you want? Caroline opens the drawer. She finds a long, sharp gold letter opener. She puts the letter opener between her tee and she crawls up on top of him. She tears his shirt open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus opens the closet. He pulls out his shirts. He find a suitcoat. A black suitcoat, and pants. He holds them up to his body and looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You know "the hooker with a heart of gold" thing? Well, that wasn't this one. She was one cold, dirty bitch. Carruthers finds a row of half-used candles, and a pendan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline opens her dark, almost black, lipstick. She begi to draw something on his chest with the lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: It's a dangerous game you're playing, Vic. There's something you need to know...I always win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers holds up the pendant. It's a pentagram.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline finishes her lipstick drawing. She has made a re pentagram on Vic's chest.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What do you want? You want money? I'll give you whatever you want. Caroline tears a piece of duct tape. She rubs her ass on his mid-section, as if trying to arouse him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I just want one tiny little insignificant thing.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What? She puts the tape over his mouth. He fights for breath.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Your life. Caroline raises the letter opener over her head. Victor's eyes go wide. She plunges the blade into his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers shows Ray the pendant.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: You mind if I take this?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: She don't need it anymore. You done? I got things.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Sure. Carruthers steps out. Ray closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline looks into Victor's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: You're a believer now, aren't you, Mr. Carruthers? He nods violently, in agony. Caroline laughs. Her face changes. She becomes the demon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus attends the graveside service. He is dressed in hi dark suit. There is a crowd of 50 in attendance. Several HOMELESS PEOPLE linger at the outer edges.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE
dialogues.text: It's not hard to believe in the devil. Just open your eyes. You see hell all around us. What happened to Emma makes it easy to believe in the devil. But it makes it hard to keep believing in God...Emma's goodness. That's what I keep thinking about. There's a reason to believe in God. Marcus looks at Emma's mother, CHARLOTTE, a beautiful wom in her mid 50's.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm tortured to think that if I were stronger, if I were smarter, I could have protected her...Evil exists, brothers and sisters. And God's not always going to protect us. He didn't protect Emma. That was our job. We've got to get smarter. We've got to get stronger. We've got to protect the goodness that's still with us. Marcus glances to a woman who walks on the outskirts of t crowd. It is Emma. She passes behind one of the mourners, and is gone. Confused, Marcus looks for her. But she does reappear.

dialogues.speaker: CARLISLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we should pray a little less, and work a little more. Fight a little more, to make this world the kind of place where our Emmas are safe...the kind of place, I think, that it has never been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers knocks on the door of a small, run-down house a shitty part of town. A woman, LINDSAY, 57, answers. Her manner is not rude, but certainly not welcoming.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Ma'am. My name is John Carruthers. I'm investigating the death of your daughter, Elizabeth...May I speak with you for a moment?  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers, a file open on his knees, sits in the small, dark house. Lindsay brings him a glass of water. The wate has a brown tint to it. He notices, and doesn't drink. She sits.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: Most people would have called first.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't have your number.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: It's in the book. I work nights. I sleep during the day.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I'm very sorry about what happened to Elizabeth. Lindsay shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The police have told me that you refused to identify her body.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: I didn't want to see my daughter when she was alive. Why would I want to see her dead?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: When was the last time you spoke with your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: Four years ago. Carruthers is suprised. Lindsay unbuttons the top button her blouse. She pulls it aside a few inches, revealing a thick, jagged scar over her left breast.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She did it, in my sleep. We argued over something. Don't remember what. She said she was going to kill me...I didn't--I couldn't believe that she meant it.  36.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't have any record of this.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: She didn't do jail time. She was sixteen years old. She went to the state hospital. They let her out after a year. She took off two days later. She said that if I ever gave her a reason, she would come back and finish the job. I believed her that time. Lindsay takes a cigarette from its pack. She offers one t Carruthers. He takes it. She lights her cigarette, then hands him the lighter.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At the hospital, they called her a, um, a sociopath. Somebody who doesn't see other people as...people, you know. They're like things to her. Playthings. Inconveniences. Carruthers lights the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's good she's dead. That paramedic they're trying to blame. They ought to give him a medal as far as I'm concerned. They're afraid I'm going to sue. I'm not going to sue anybody. The night after she died...I haven't slept that well in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsay walks Carruthers to his car. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: LINDSAY
dialogues.text: You know, she wasn't always that way. As a little girl, she was real sweet. Then she got bad sick when she was 14. Fevers...she even died for a few minutes. Her heart failed. They brought her back, but she was never the same. She was mean. Dark, you know. It's like the fever did something to her brain. My little girl died when she was 14. This whore you're talking to me about...she was nothing to me. A woman watches from the opposite side of the street. She is partly obscured by one of the large trees that line th road, but we see a part of her face. It is Caroline.  37. Carruthers starts his car. He drives away. Lindsay watche him go. She sees Caroline across the street, but she does not know her. Lindsay walks back toward her house. Caroli doesn't move. A man approaches, walking two Rottweiler do The man is bearded and wears wire rimmed glasses with sma circular lenses. His hair and clothing are wild and rumpl This is MARTINEAU, 42. The dogs begin to growl and bark at Caroline. Martineau does his best to hold them back.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINEAU
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. They're usually not-- The dogs look like they want to tear her apart. Caroline gives the man and his dogs a cold look. She starts away. The dogs settle. Martineau watches Caroline go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several people from the funeral linger in and around Emma house. It is an old brick home, built in the 1920's. Marc climbs the front steps, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus pours himself a cup of red punch. Carlisle stands the kitchen doorway with Charlotte. He sees Marcus and gi him a welcoming smile. Marcus nods to him and puts a coup of cookies on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers approaches the door to his office. He's surpri that it's locked. He unlocks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus tries the door to the bathroom. It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus climbs the stairs. He sees a bathroom at the end o the hall. He starts toward it. As he passes, he looks int one of the bedrooms. It is clearly Emma's. The bed is mad the curtains are open. He stops in the doorway. He sees a small writing desk nea the window. Several volumes of a diary are neatly stacked on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers enters. He starts toward his office. He looks Victor's door. It is crawling with flies.  38.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers pushes the door open and scatters a cloud of f He enters, then stops dead in his tracks. Victor lies disemboweled on the desk. Caroline has painte the walls with his innards. Written in blood across the wall are the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus stands at Emma's desk. He opens one of her diaries On the first page is Emma's photo. There is a soft knock on the door. He looks up. Emma's mother, Charlotte, stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Oh. Excuse me. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: It's alright. I know we all...want to be close to her again. Somehow. He stands there awkwardly. He doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you go to school with her?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: No, ma'am...I--I met her at the shelter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Do you read Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Charlotte sit in the window seat. Emma's diari are between them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: She kept a diary. Every day...I-- I've been trying to read it, trying to find some reason for what happened. Marcus turns a page. The writing is in Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her father was from Argentina. He taught her, before he died. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every entry...is a letter to him. I-- I can't read Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Where do you want me to start? Charlotte nods to the book in his hand. He looks down.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading) "Dear Papa, today there was an earthquake in Peru. I saw pictures of a man holding his little boy who had died. The little boy's legs were covered with blood."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers sits outside Vic's door as POLICE OFFICERS swa the office. A PHOTOGRAPHER photographs Vic's body.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "You could see the pain in the father's face. Pain so deep it will never go away." A DETECTIVE transcribes the writing on the wall. He sees Vic's discarded innards, his heart, on the floor. A POLIC dusts the open file cabinet for fingerprints.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I know the boy is in a better place. I won't pray for him tonight." A woman approaches. We recognize her from the family phot It is Vic's wife, ROSIE. She sees the police and starts t lose it. Carruthers immediately rises and grabs her. She screams. He pulls her close. She sobs into his chest.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "I'll pray for his father. And his mother, wherever she is." Vic's children, MICAH, 7, and CHANDRA, 5, walk toward the in the hallway. Carruthers leads Rosie toward them.

dialogues.speaker: MICAH
dialogues.text: Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: C'mon, babies. We got to go.

dialogues.speaker: CHANDRA
dialogues.text: I want to go to Daddy's office.  40.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Not today, honey. C'mon now. We got to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille wipes a tear from her face.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (reading) "And his brothers and sisters. All of those who loved him and who are hurting so bad tonight."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers leads Rosie and the children back to the stair He passes a cop, FRANK, 47, at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Frank, I can't stay. Will you...?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'll take care of everything. I'll let you know what we find. John, God. I'm sorry. Vic was a good man.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Carruthers starts down the stairs with Rosie and the kids

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Rosie) Vic backs up his laptop at the house, right? She nods, fighting emotion.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've got to get into those files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed exits Marcus's house. He slams the door behind him. Carla immediately follows. She is hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: No! Come back here!

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You're out of your goddamn mind! He goes to his car. She grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Please! Don't leave me!  41.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me! Are you crazy? He pushes her back. She falls on the front lawn, and sobs

dialogues.speaker: ED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cutting yourself. What the hell is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Don't leave me...

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You're out of your goddamn mind. He starts the car. He drives away. Carla sobs on the fron lawn. A NEIGHBOR woman has stopped on the sidewalk. She watches.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT ARE YOU LOOKING AT
dialogues.text: The neighbor turns away, and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus approaches Emma's grave. He puts a flower at the base of the mound of dirt.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I only knew you for twenty minutes... And you were the best person I've ever known. Marcus's cell phone rings. He looks at the phone. Carla i calling. He decides to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla is at the bathroom mirror, with the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Goodbye. She hangs up.  42.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Carla?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla, weeping, raises a handful of pills to her mouth. S washes them down with a glass of water. The phone begins ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus, the phone to his ear, walks quickly toward his ca The phone is ringing, but there's no answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Dammit. He gets into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus speeds down the road. He's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Jen, it's me. Get over to the house. It's Carla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny is on the phone. Shawn is driving.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (into phone) What? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Okay. We're on it. Shawn turns the ambulance around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus bursts into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Carla!  43. He goes immediately toward the bathroom. He finds Carla. She has collapsed on the hallway floor. He rolls her over. She's unconscious. He slaps her face. She mumbles, but doesn't open her eyes. He drags her to t bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus drags Carla to the toilet. He grabs the empty bott of pills on the counter and reads the label. He angrily throws the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Come on, Carla. Wake up for me. He bends her over the toilet and he forces two fingers do her throat. She chokes, gags, then vomits into the toilet

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go. That's a good girl. He gags her again. She vomits again. Shawn and Jenny appe in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: What did she do?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: It's alright. I got her in time.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (sees the pill bottle) We taking her in?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Give me the kit. Hold her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla lies in the bed. She is lethargic, but conscious. Marcus sits at her side. Jenny's in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I think we ought to take her in.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: (softly, to Marcus) If you let them put me in the psych unit, I'll finish it. I swear to God I will. Jen leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: It's alright. It's gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen stops in the hallway, at the bathroom door. Shawn sit on the edge of the tub. He has cleaned up the mess. He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: He deserves a lot better. Shawn silently, reluctantly, agrees. Jenny walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers tucks his grandkids into bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHANDRA
dialogues.text: Grandpa, can you sleep over tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I'm not going anywhere. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers scans files in Vic's home office. He looks at Vic's calendar, his schedule of meetings. He stops momentarily to look at his son's photograph on t desk. We see another photograph, Vic on a bowling team wi Geoff, the man who jumped to his death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsay, the dead hooker's mother, is dressed in her nightgown. She pours herself a cup of hot water. We see her through the kitchen doorway, as if we are spying on h She puts a tea bag into the water, then some sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsay washes her face at the bathroom sink. The mirror the medicine cabinet is open a few inches. She lifts her head and dries her face on a towel. She loo at herself in the mirror. She notices that the mirror is little askew. She reaches to correct it. She closes the cabinet door. And we see...that there was nothing waiting behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsay sits on the edge of her bed and finishes her tea. She lies down. She takes a black cloth eye mask from the night stand and puts it on. As the black cloth covers her eyes, we are left in total darkness.  45. In the darkness, we hear only Lindsay's tired breathing a the slight rustle of the sheets as she moves. We hear the creak of a floorboard. Lindsay's calm breathing continues She does not seem alarmed. Then we hear the creak of the springs on the bed. Lindsay breathing stops. She utters a small, odd questioning soun As she takes off the eye mask, we see what she sees: Caroline is kneeling over her. She holds a large kitchen knife over her head in both hands.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Hi, mom. And she brings the knife down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers continues to work at Vic's computer. He's now looking at case files. His cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Carruthers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, the cop, walks down the hall and talks into his ce phone. INTERCUT WITH INT. VIC'S DEN.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The prints match a lady named Caroline Kuntz. You know her?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: No. Rosie steps into the doorway and looks at Carruthers. Her face is puffy from crying. She wears a robe, and she's holding a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nothing in the criminal database. But we found her in the state employee file. She's single. Elemenary school teacher. Lives in Midvale.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: (to Rosie, covering the phone) You know a Caroline Kuntz? She shakes her head.  46.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Here's where it really gets weird. This Kuntz lady is at a PTA meeting two nights ago. She has some kind of seizure. Rosie puts a pill in her mouth. She washes it down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Freaks everybody out. Ambulance comes, they take her away, she flat-— lines. She's dead for, like, four minutes. They bring her back. They take her to the hospital, put her in a bed, and she disappears.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Disappears?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She takes down a nurse and a janitor and then just walks out of the hospital. They got it on surveillance. Nobody's seen her since.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Why would a schoolteacher want to kill Vic?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We're talking to her friends, family. The really weird thing is, before two nights ago, this woman was Mother Teresa. Carruthers watches Rosie take another pill. At the precin an OFFICE COP hands Frank a file.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Thanks. (hangs up. To Rosie...) On Vic's calendar, he had appointments with a Father Vernon. Every other day for the past two weeks. You know what that's about?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus lies in bed with Carla. They are both awake. She lies with her back to him. He rises.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus, at the kitchen counter, pours himself a glass of whiskey. This time he drinks it. And he pours himself another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers has the newspaper article about Geoff's death open on the computer. He compares the photo to the bowlin photo on Vic's desk. He sighs. He opens a case file named simply, "Geoff." Rosie is asleep on the office couch. She stirs, but doesn wake. Carruthers reads the file.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Vic...what the hell were you playing with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers walks down the center aisle of a beautiful Cat cathedral. He doesn't stop to genuflect. There are a half dozen WOMEN scattered in the aisles, pra A priest, FATHER VERNON, 52, is lighting candles. Carruth approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Father Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER VERNON
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: (extends his hand) John Carruthers. Victor was my son. Vernon's expression immediately softens with compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers and Father Vernon sit on a pew in a long administrative hallway of the cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I have a pretty good idea what happened. I just need you to fill in the blanks.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER VERNON
dialogues.text: What is said in my confessional will remain in the confessional, even in death. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER VERNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he hands Carruthers a letter) Your son asked me to give this to you, in the event of his passing. I expect it will answer many of your questions. Carruthers looks at the letter.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER VERNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were hired to investigate the death of the prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Markham. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER VERNON
dialogues.text: Victor felt it wasn't a coincidence. It was God's justice. Finding him. (A moment, then...) Victor's sins were very great. He was afraid...he was convinced...that he had lost his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers sits in a pew near the back of the cathedral. reads Vic's letter. He wipes tears from his face. Father Vernon watches from a doorway near the front. He turns aw and exits, leaving Carruthers alone in the cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny and Shawn pound on Marcus's front door.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: C'mon. Open the door. Marcus opens. Some time has passed since we last saw him. He's a mess. He hasn't shaved in days. His white t-shirt is no longer white.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Hey, yourself.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: We're here to congratulate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn and Jenny enter the house. Marcus closes the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you haven't heard...you're off suspension.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Suspension.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Remember? The dead hooker. Ring any bells?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It stinks in here. Somebody turn on the lights.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: As soon as Henderson got word that the family wasn't gonna sue, he decided not to continue the investigation. Imagine that. Marcus turns on the light. The place is a goddamn mess. There are beer and whiskey bottles everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Just what the hell have you been doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Translating. I got a translating job. He motions to the table. Emma's journals are open, a half-empty whiskey bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: So do you eat anything anymore or just...? Shawn steps into the doorway to the bedroom. Carla is in bed, her back to us.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Hey, Carla. How you feeling? She's awake, but she doesn't answer. Shawn turns away.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I know what it looks like. We're just...going through some stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Going through some brain cells, that's for sure.  50.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Look, it's really none of anybody's goddamn business.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Oookay.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, girl. A man's gotta do what a man's gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Well, a man's gotta take a shower eventually.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Yeah, we gotta get your ass cleaned up, man. Parker quit yesterday so...you can take his shift if you want. Starts at three.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Three?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: If you want it.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Yeah. I want it.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Alright! The man is back on the job!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (to Shawn) You throw him in the shower. I'll...turn the hose on this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cleaned up and back in uniform, sits on the edge of

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: If you need me, just call. Carla doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta go. He starts to rise. She quickly turns and grabs his arm. Her eyes are full of fear, despair.  51.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's just one shift. I'll take my cell...I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus gets in Jenny's car. Shawn is in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It's the house of the dead in there. You realize that. Marcus looks at the house. He sighs. Jenny starts the eng

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers knocks, then waits at a door. He's dressed ina dark suit. Ray opens.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: You and I need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: We already talked. He starts to close the door. Carruthers puts up a hand an stops the door.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: I buried my boy this morning. I'm in no mood to play games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers sits at Ray's dining table. This place is a du

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Eight days ago, a man named Geoff Morgan took a dive off a building downtown. Family man, good job. No reason to kill himself. Carruthers puts a photo on the table. It is the photo of Vic and Geoff on the bowling team.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know this man? Ray shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a liar. This man was a friend of my son's, and he was one of your customers. Lizzie Markham, your hooker, was blackmailing him. He borrowed $25,000 from my son, and he paid her.  52.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I didn't blackmail anybody.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: She asked for more. He wouldn't pay it. My son looked into things. Then he made another withdrawal from his bank account. $20,000. He didn't give that to his friend. He didn't give that to Lizzie Markham. He paid that to you.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I said, I didn't blackmail--.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: My son paid you twenty thousand dollars to make this problem go away. Ray looks at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My son hired you to kill Lizzie Markham. You shot her full of bad drugs.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You're out of your fucking mind. Ray moves to get up. Carruthers rises, fast, and slams hi against the wall. He presses his forearm against Ray's throat.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: Who killed my son? We hear the sliding pump of a shotgun as someone loads a shell into the chamber. Carruthers turns his head. A youn hooker, PETRA, 15, stands in the doorway, the shotgun rea

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Get out of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carruthers gets into his car outside the crackhouse. He looks up at the second floor window. Ray, shotgun in hand looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: CARRUTHERS
dialogues.text: You're going down, asshole. He starts the car, and pulls away.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance waits, lights blazing, near the front door a strip club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcus and Jenny attend to a heavy-set 55 year-old man, THOMAS. Thomas lies on the floor, on his back. A few club patrons remain. Four STRIPPERS watch. They wear flimsy robes. The D.J. checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Pulse is 150.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: I was just giving him a dance. Next thing I know, he falls on the floor. Jenny reads his blood pressure.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Sixty over forty.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Alright, Thomas. We've got to get you to a hospital. I think you're having a little heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Don't...tell my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: My job's just to keep that heart working. If you can help me do that, you can tell your wife whatever you want. Is that a deal?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Thomas, I think this hobby's getting a little dangerous for you. Maybe you ought to take up golf. Thomas gives her a confused look.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (to Jenny) I've played golf. Doesn't quite compare.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car passes Josie, the hooker, who is standing at the curb. A woman approaches slowly. Josie sees her. It is Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Caroline looks at her, but doesn't speak.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What're you looking at? You somebody's wife?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Oh no. Josie turns her attention back to the street.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Josie.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a date.

dialogues.speaker: JOSIE
dialogues.text: I don't do women. Caroline produces a thick wad of cash. Josie decides that maybe she does do women after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie leads Caroline up the stairs of the crackhouse. Ray takes his place at the top of the stairs. He sits in a ch next to Josie's door. Petra sits on his lap. Josie gives Ray a few bills as she passes. Ray looks at Caroline. Josie unlocks her door.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (to Josie) How long?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: As long as it takes, Ray. They enter, and close the door. Petra playfully tries to grab the money.  55.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Greedy little bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie leads Caroline down a short hallway, past a small bathroom, and into a bedroom. The apartment is pretty muc what you'd expect: orderly but with an air of decay. It i furnished and decorated with a low-rent attempt at sensua Caroline stops in the doorway. She takes off her coat. Josie, at the bed, starts to unbutton her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: No. Let me do that.
